output: First of all, I would like to congratulate Mr. Siebe for the work he has done, because in his report many of the concerns expressed in this case

I want to make a comment on these crucial problems for the entire European Union. These are the lack of water and drought, issues that have ceased to be only a problem in the countries of southern Europe.

I am pleased that this project incorporates some of the reflections made in the opinion report of which I was a speaker in the Agriculture Commission in favour of an agricultural activity, highlighting, for example, the role that farmers play in the sustainable management of available resources.

It also includes a reference to drought and water scarcity as factors that aggravate prices in raw materials, an aspect in which the times that run also seem very important to me to point out, so that we may not only have in mind the environmental dimension of this problem, but also some of its most relevant economic consequences.

The Environmental Commission included, on the other hand, the idea of creating a European drought observatory, an action that is mentioned in the report of the Commission on Agriculture and that I hope will be reflected in concrete facts.

The text submitted tomorrow to vote, however, includes a proposal made by the Agriculture Commission to study the implementation of an economic adaptation fund against drought, a fund that would benefit all economic sectors, including agriculture.

I would like to make it clear that I will continue to defend the constitution of this fund, an idea that I will propose to the Parliament again when the communication that the Commission has planned to publish on the adaptation to climate change arrives in the coming months.

I think that after the Solidarity Fund was established, which was created to alleviate the losses caused by climate disasters, it is time to think about an instrument that acts a priori and is intended to finance prevention measures to reduce the environmental and economic cost of these climate disasters.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, terrorism is a global phenomenon and the action of serious organized crime as well. Therefore, the means must be proportional and must be fought with efficiency.

I have taken good note of the answers to the questions that were appropriate. It is true that guarantees must be demanded. It is true that it is a delicate issue, but it is certainly not without reason that it is absolutely inexcusable to form a globalized and harmonized response.
For some, terrorism is a little far away, and they are more concerned about individual qualities.
I am concerned about the individual and the collective. And it is absolutely necessary that we start wherever we can.
If we start with the air transport, where companies already have that data, let's start there.

We demand guarantees. Let's see what the scope of application is. Let's start with international transport relations. And, beware, we will have to follow the internal ones because terrorists often do not come from outside but from within.

and the reality is that there is a national reality in which there are 27 countries with different legal systems and with very different languages, which means that in each of those countries we adjust to the realities of the country, including the issue of languages.

In conclusion, I think that the Commission has done well in presenting this report

and starting from the foundations of the reality of an union that is being built, that has different national ordinances and that has different levels of access to electronic communication.

Thank you, President. A large majority of farmers and cattle farmers are pending decisions and previous agreements that the Council of Ministers of Agriculture of the Union will adopt between today and tomorrow on this check of the

because it is not a simple revision, but it will bring with it profound changes, such as the disappearance of many exploits. This is the conclusion of this report proposed by the European Commission on Direct Assistance.

Modulation is the central point of this parliamentary report and could be one of the few elements of the Parliament's opinion with some impact on the negotiations that the ministers of agriculture of the Union maintain.
We have been opposing any increase in what we euphemistically call modulation for years, because if the rural development policy does not have sufficient funds, it is not
due to lack of resources within the roof of the PAC's expenses, but due to an absolute lack of political will to provide the community budget for this necessary development pillar.
Do they want to liberalize the markets?
Of course, do it, but with equal requirements and conditions for all producers, those from within and outside the union.

At this moment, the European Union is playing the future of many farmers and cattle farmers, and I would like to make a reference to the fragile sectors such as the wine, tobacco and tobacco, whose survival in many production areas will depend on this check.

Some producers, such as the wine producers, no longer ask for help, but simply want to be let go of the market, because they have made accounts and the only way to survive is to reduce the volumes produced.

The abandonment of production is the only way out for many producers, whose space will undoubtedly be occupied by imports from third countries, because the consumer will not stop consuming and the world will not stop increasing the number of consumers.
The Parliament should issue a prudent opinion and the Council should listen to it.

I think the important thing at this point in the debate is to send a message of stability for our farmers.
European farmers need more than ever stability and solutions.
It is necessary to have enough transit periods, as well as to maintain specific measures that are necessary for sectors in difficulty.
Madam Commissioner, the same solutions are not valid for all sectors.
We must remember that we have sectors that are going through real difficulties.
Common agricultural policy should not be the problem, but the solution. And for this we need a first strong pillar.
We believe and we bet on rural development, but we do not believe that the modulation proposed by the Commission is the solution.
It is not about strengthening rural development in the detriment of the first pillar.
We agree that the single payment regime must be simplified, and that the market instruments must be reviewed.
but that doesn't mean to dismantle them.
If we do it right, we will be setting the foundations for a common agrarian policy beyond 2013. If not, we will be ending the activity of many European farmers.
We are facing a very long-awaited plan for the fruit and vegetable sector, not only for the difficulties it faces, but also for the worrying decline in consumption.
we are facing a public health promotion plan. I think it should be a European plan and I also defend the full community funding.

I do not agree that parents can get into co-financing because it will be the same as always. Parents who can provide money, their children, in schools will consume fruits and vegetables and those who do not will be left out of the program.
I think it has to be a plan financed by the community, so that its distribution is homogeneous.
That is why I also want to emphasize that we must put emphasis on educational measures

It is not only about a student eating an apple, but also about knowing what kind of apple he is eating, knowing its nutritional properties and understanding the beneficial effects that these fruits have for his health and development.
Of course, it must be a product with all the quality guarantees, giving priority to seasonal fruits and, when possible, I defend the community origin of our fruits and vegetables.

I think that the benefits of this plan, which I applaud and for which I want to congratulate the Commissioner, we will notice immediately. Of course, for the present and future health of our children and their education
but also very important for the fruit and vegetable sector, a productive sector that constitutes a true European cultural heritage. Thanks to it we can enjoy a balanced, healthy and varied diet.
I think it is worth investing in this distribution plan of fruits and vegetables in our schools.
I think the budget is a bit short because I defend the full community funding of such an ambitious plan.

In 2007, almost 300,000 highly qualified Europeans left the EU to work.
Let's do everything we can to keep them in the European House.

Mr. President, on behalf of the Socialist Group I want to express my most energetic repulsion to the murders that are taking place in this region of Somalia, invoking the name of God.
Few atrocities have been committed by someone who has not invoked the name of God or a religion.

Specifically, the way in which this atrocious murder was committed, as we know, a 13-year-old girl who is raped and then accused of adultery, and five men, if they can be called men, rush to lapidate her and even prevent someone from trying to save her, in a stadium occupied by a thousand people.
This, combined with the acts of piracy that this year in the coasts of Somalia have reached the level of almost 100 boats kidnapped, constitutes an absolutely unacceptable humanitarian situation.
The international community cannot remain impassive about this.
It cannot remain impassive in the face of cowardice, in the face of the religious invocation to commit barbarities,
Therefore, we must restore order by supporting the legitimate government of Somalia to regain control of the entire country and establish a state of law that respects human rights.

We have a resolution proposal about Nicaragua in which we have to take different aspects.
First of all, there is a fraud allegation, at least in two municipalities, Nicaragua and León, and this hinders the election result of November 9.
On the other hand, we have a government that has been concerned about solving some of the problems that eliminate human rights in Latin America.
specifically poverty, illiteracy, infant mortality, drinking water and the lack of ownership over indigenous lands.
So, when we examine the case, we have to distinguish perfectly the two aspects.

On the one hand, we have to stimulate human rights and we have to defend human rights in the traditional sense as political rights. And on the other hand, we have to encourage the government of Nicaragua to continue its function of helping the most needy sectors of the country.
Of course, we have to guarantee that the opposition can exercise its function, we have to oppose fraud, but we have to defend the performance of the UNHCR.
However, we must have a balanced result.
The Socialist Group has presented several oral amendments, trying to frame the definitive text so that it is more balanced, regarding the allegations of
violations of fundamental rights, regarding the criminal nature or not of the investigations, and regarding the number of municipalities in which the effect has occurred some kind of derogation.

In short, we want to condemn the alleged infraction of fundamental political rights, but without reaching the extreme of placing the government of Nicaragua in a difficult situation to continue to fulfill its function of support to the most needed layers of society.
...about the situation created in Nicaragua by the attacks against some human rights defenders, against some fundamental freedoms and against democracy.

It is not necessary to remember here and now to Soy la América, or to Ernesto Cardenal, or to Carlos Mejía Godoy, or to Jarquin, or to Sergio Ramírez, or to so many other Nicaraguans who today feel betrayed in their hopes for a better Nicaragua.
In November 2006, Mr. Ortega asked and obtained, democratically, from the Nicaraguans what he called a new opportunity.
Today we know why he wanted her.
Since then, arbitrariness, nepotism and corruption have been installed in government institutions, which have culminated with electoral fraud in the elections of November 9.

Before, very serious decisions had been made, such as the cancellation of the legal personality of some opposition parties, threats and intimidation of members of civil society, journalists and media.
President Ortega called the EU governments as flies that fly over the filth and called the external aid received by Nicaragua as crutches.
soon understood that there was not enough Venezuelan oil to prevent this help to the development.

When we are about to enter a decisive phase of the negotiation of an agreement of association of the European Union and Central America, the Government of Nicaragua must know that in us will always find an ally and a friend,

But for us, the demand for respect for human rights, freedom of expression and democracy in general is a condition to which we do not give up because we believe that it benefits especially the people of Nicaragua.
Last November 9, the municipal elections in Nicaragua were held.
As in previous occasions, this electoral process has been put in the open from the point of view of democratic legitimacy, having poured accusations of fraud and having occurred
and confrontations between supporters of different political parties with the result of numerous injuries and a deepening in the political crisis that this country has been suffering.
Two political parties could not be present at the local elections, which is unacceptable because it violates the fundamental right of all citizens to political participation.

On the other hand, we have received direct testimonies from representatives of human rights organizations that have informed us about the existence of a questioning of the judicial system by the civil society

on the existence of administrative mechanisms of repression that have led to the courts up to 17 organizations of social movements, on persecution of independent journalists and even the delegation of the European Commission.

For all this, we want to raise our voice and make a call, first to the political parties to condemn the acts of violence carried out by their followers, and second to the government itself to reopen spaces for civil participation

that freedom of expression is respected, that marches are stopped and that all NGOs can receive help from international cooperation, not only those of Venezuela, for the pro-governmentalist associations.
Likewise, to derogate the penalization of therapeutic abortion in cases of danger to the life of the mother.

Finally, we also want to ask the Commission to remember that the negotiations of the agreement of association between Central America and the European Union in Nicaragua must respect the principles of the rule of law

democracy and human rights, all of this without the harm of the fact that we continue to lend our help to the development and well-being of the Nicaraguan people, who wish to have the best possible future.
Thank you, Mrs. President. I am referring to the Breyer report.
I must say that European farmers are fully aware that the use of phytosanitary products should pay particular attention to human health and also to the protection of the environment.
However, the sector is deeply concerned because the European Parliament does not understand the impact that this regulation may have in the future.
There are evaluations of its potential impact that indicate that due to the low availability of future phytosanitary products,

...the control of pests and diseases that affect the cultivation of a large amount of food......in particular, all Mediterranean products and also the cultivation of ornamental plants and cut flowers.
I am fully aware that the agreement adopted in the dialogue between the three sides has been the result of a lot of negotiation and I cannot but acknowledge the work that the speakers have done.

However, we must take into account that the temporal definition of the endocrine disruptors will lead to the disappearance of a large number of active substances, especially insecticides, of key importance for agriculture.

The producers must have at their disposal enough active substances to effectively and safely combat any disease or plague of the plants, taking into account that many times the danger is not in the product, but in the misuse of it.
For all this, the Spanish delegation of the PP-Edei group supports the proposals that request the evaluation of an impact and will vote in favour of amendments
of Mr. Stardi, which I have signed myself, relating to endocrine disruptors and those that favor the availability of phytosanitary products in case of emergency.

Furthermore, if this regulation is adopted in the terms of the agreement, the effects will be a reduction in food production and a rise in prices, which will lead us to import those same foods that we do not produce, treated with the products that we are producing.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Capato, your report is a report that is full of goodwill. The most evident proof is that it did not deserve any amendment in its implementation during the Commission on Liberties.
You were the one who introduced 18 amendments to your own report.
And those amendments are the ones that have introduced to this report a radical plus, let's say, in general terms, which raises very serious doubts.

I would propose in four different statements the amendments that you have proposed. You have proposed them yourself, I insist, in a report that received the support of all the groups at the beginning.
Some are impossible. You ask for some things that are impossible.

For example, Mr Capato, you ask for things for which there is no legal basis yet. For example, as long as the Lisbon Treaty does not come into force, it will be impossible to harmonize the regulations of different commissions.

something similar to what the Commissioner of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs just said. Or you ask, for example, that we declare the year 2009 the year of transparency. We are late, there is no longer a deadline.
So you are asking for impossible things.
It also asks for some other things that are not advisable.
For example, you ask for transparency in political groups meetings.
No, man, no.
Because we need privacy, and privacy is a political asset
If I want to discrepate with my party, to maintain an opposition, I want to do it in private and that is not a lack of transparency.
Transparency must be demanded in public bodies, but not in the heart of the parties where debates must be guaranteed within privacy.
so I can't follow him on that.
There are some other appreciations that you make, Mr. Capato, that are uncertain.
For example, you say that 90% of the legislative activity is pro-comitology.
That's a dreadful exaggeration, Mr. Capato.
And also, the chymontology has implicitly some rules of transparency in itself.
If we are going to make more mechanisms, more bureaucracy, more controls, we will be going against what we want to pursue, which is transparency, which is something that is very close to simplicity.
And finally, before the president calls my attention, because I'm consuming my time, there are some things that are unnecessary.
For example, I understand that it is very boring and very attractive for public opinion to say transparency in the activity of the deputies, that it is known that they come to the plenum,
We already know, Mr. Capato.
or that go to the commissions, you know, if there is an act of all of them, they are accessible acts for all citizens.
or the money they charge, we already know, Mr. Capato.
It is perfectly possible for a citizen to have access to that information.

Therefore, I understand that it is very mollar in the face of public opinion and that it adorns a lot to defend transparency, but I want you to know that transparency is to make things look as they are. And when one contributes that things do not look as they are, Mr. Capato, then we are not contributing to transparency.
Thank you for your generosity, Mr. President.

Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. As we can see, in recent times the textile sector is undergoing an important crisis, which has caused numerous closures of companies, dislocations and unemployment, which are precisely the reasons for the focus of regions specialising in this activity.

Faced with this current economic crisis situation, the European Commission should act quickly alongside the Member States to alleviate the socio-economic effects of this restructuring, especially dramatic for the affected territories and families.

I think it is necessary to provide help to workers in the textile sector and in the manufacturing sector with social measures, with plans for companies that are the object of restructuring and that are in serious trouble at the moment.
It would be desirable to allocate a substantial part of the Globalization Adaptation Fund to the restructuring and re-qualification of the textile sector.
particularly small and medium-sized companies that are part of the European Union sector and that suffer the effects of market liberalisation to a greater extent.
On the other hand, it is necessary to restore the import control system from abroad and, especially, due to its volume, from China.
It is not at all about promoting commercial barriers
It is about compensating the negative effects of such an important transformation. And we should not forget that the European Union is the second world exporter of textile products and clothing.

which makes it necessary to guarantee the best access conditions to the markets of third countries, essential for the future of the textile industry and the production with headquarters in the European Union and especially for the PYME.
All this, of course, always guaranteeing a loyal competition based on the promotion of environmental and social norms in these countries.

In this sense, the publication of the correct information to the consumer, for example, with the regulation on the indication made in, which, as we know, has not been implemented, would be of great use,
...which would imply subjecting imported products to the same safety and protection requirements......as those manufactured within the European Union.

Mr. President, there are several cases of European historical peoples' own languages that, because they are not constituted in the State, are not allowed to be used in the debates of this Parliament. This is a democratic and representative deficit.

One of these cases is the Basque-Euskera language, which is not a minority language but an official one, at least in the southern part of the Basque Country, which administratively is part of the Spanish State.

But the same thing does not happen, and let's not take it personally, with the Basque country of the North, which has signed the French state, whose president, before the UN Assembly, affirms that denying respect to national identities and languages is to feed humiliation and that without that respect there will be no peace in the world.
And then neither the Euskera, nor the Corsican, Breton or Occitan have the slightest official consideration or have the support to respect or promote their use.

Therefore, I ask the Fundamental Rights Agency to work so that within the Member States the rights of the mother tongue of any European people are not violated, nor are their inhabitants discriminated against, and that all of them are considered official within their respective territories.
I would like to thank you for your support.

Thank you, Madam President. First of all, I would like to thank our opponent, Claudio Fava, for his great work in achieving a common position with the Council, which includes many improvements proposed by our Chamber.
With this directive we again demonstrate our commitment to the construction of a common migratory policy based on a global approach.
The proposal of this directive is clear. Fight against the mafia, punish the unscrupulous employers and protect the exploited immigrants who do not have any kind of social protection.

We want the unfair poverty salaries to disappear for immigrants and that they also distribute the average salaries, especially in sectors such as construction, the countryside, the domestic service or the hostelry.
These measures need great courage and political will, as there are many interests created and a lot of money that is being spent on the submerged economy.
Precisely in difficult times, it is more important than ever to manage migratory flows intelligently, generously, but with responsibility.
the easy thing would be to fall into the temptation of not trying to block the submerged economy.
We cannot look to the other side and leave about 8 million irregular immigrants in a situation of indefence, with labor conditions close to slavery.

Ladies and gentlemen, if we want this directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic and even criminal sanctions are necessary in the most serious cases that have a dissuasive effect on businessmen.
We will be able to reduce the submerged economy and cut the migration incentive that generates the possibility of working irregularly.
It should be clear that the only option to work in Europe is the legal way.

Therefore, we want to move forward with the global approach and we ask the Commission, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Baró, to present as soon as possible the new blue cards, in quotation marks, for the other working categories.
Dear colleagues, Mrs. Ferreiro Balner, Mr. Solana, I would like to thank the three speakers for their work. And while I am a speaker in the shadow of the report on PESC, I will refer to
to this report in particular, starting by congratulating Mr. Sarisbolski for the result of his work and for the collaboration that he has offered to the other groups to achieve a consensus result.

In the same way that this Parliament has claimed on numerous occasions that the European Union has the necessary instruments to speak with a single voice in the world, the Chamber itself knows how to show cohesion around the evaluation and the promotion of major priorities in foreign policy and common security.

The commitment of our socialist group has gone in two directions. On the one hand, to introduce or reinforce major issues that are key to us in a transversal way to all foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of

...or a bet on human development. On the other hand, we proposed elements of re-balancing......the geographical priorities of the PESC......regarding how they originally appeared in the text......or introducing them as new elements if they were absent.

In this way, we have advocated, for example, for a greater clarification of the relations between the institutional frameworks of cooperation involved in the Eastern dimension, which was recently defined.
We have defended a greater diversification and a greater relevance of relations with Africa, a continent of which we often only agree when special war violence occurs, and many times not even so.

Regarding Latin America, we have wanted the current negotiation processes to be reflected in the association agreements, the first of a bi-regional nature that the European Union will conclude throughout its history.

As for the Mediterranean, we have opposed a reductionist approach that only speaks of security, to include, on the other hand, all the rich political, economic and socio-cultural wealth contained in the process of Barcelona.

Regarding amendments to the Plenum, our group has not presented any, believing that, in some way, the balance achieved with the commitments is strengthened and, therefore, we will oppose most of the amendments to not weaken the commitment reached by the Foreign Commission. Thank you.
Thank you, President. The Venezuelan referendum has been held with a yes triumph, elegantly recognized by the democratic opposition.

It is not less true that there has been no equality of opportunities in the campaign and that the officialism has had the overwhelming support of the entire State apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even in these conditions, the country has been practically divided into two halves and it will be very difficult to build the future with only one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion and consensus between Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not with visceral attitudes, disqualifications or insults that we will help Venezuela find its democratic, pluralist and free path.

In this sense, we criticize the Venezuelan government's decision to expel a Spanish eurodiputado and much more the ways in which such an expulsion was carried out. But we call upon this Chamber to avoid

that our representatives make declarations on their visit to third countries that violate the current local legislation and even less that they insult a head of state, no matter how much this is critical.
With these attitudes we are compromising future missions of the European Parliament to other countries.
Mr. President, I just arrived from Venezuela, where I was invited by your electoral power as a member of an international electoral support group for the referendum of the last 15 days.

The members of this group have raised a report to the National Electoral Council with a positive global assessment of the process in terms of its organization, transparency, participation, free and secret exercise of the right to vote and security in all its phases.

On the statements of the deputy Herrero to a Venezuelan television, he pointed out that they were coming to delegitimize the electoral process in progress, they put serious accusations against democratic institutions of that country, they scratch on the interference in the internal policy of a sovereign country.
Our Parliament should not propitiate any kind of confrontation with the democratic institutions of Venezuela,
On the contrary, it would be up to the Deputy to give explanations to this Chamber about an action that affects all of us.
The Commission of Budgetary Affairs believes that the clear allocation of each of the budgetary instruments is of the utmost importance.

Therefore, the most realistic option seems to be the creation of a new instrument for different actions of public assistance to the development of the countries that enter the scope of application of this regulation.
From a budgetary point of view, it seems inadequate the proposal of funding from the Development Commission, since this money does not exist,
...with a quantity of credit assigned pluriannually. There is a credit for 2009, but not for beyond.
In any case, since the financing of this new instrument of cooperation must be compatible with the financial framework 2007-2013,
I would like to remind you of the importance of the intermediate review of the financial framework, which should allow an adjustment of the maximum limits of the different categories.
Well, this late Monday, the Commission will probably have other things to worry about than this report.
In conclusion, what we are doing is just answering a report from the Commission, a report on the application of Regulation 1206-2001
of May 28, 2001, relating to cooperation between the jurisdictional bodies of the member states in the field of obtaining evidence in civil or mercantile matters.

We are in an area that is really not community, it is an intergovernmental area in which, from the council through the regulation, it has been tried to stimulate cooperation between those legal bodies.
But in doing so, I think there is a certain lack of rigor by the European Union.

I mean, certain measures have been foreseen, for example, the issue of practical guidelines, the use of electronic media, etc. But I recognize that it is quite difficult for a commission to take action

I don't know what the Commission has achieved or what it plans to achieve, but I find it quite difficult to achieve it due to the enormous difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation constitutes.

We are asking the judicial authorities that collaborate with each other, we are talking about 27 countries, judicial authorities that manage 22 different languages, with very different legal systems between each other, and we are trying to achieve results.
The Commission has found that the results are not good, that there is a huge delay in these cooperation mechanisms and, of course, that we do not have the means to do so.
Ideally, we would have material means
For example, what could the Commission do to provide the judicial bodies, especially those of a lower level of technological elements, with a videoconference system?
The videoconference can be a utopia of many small judges of the European Union, but it seems to be the only way to do it.
I think that the European Union should rely on existing institutions, specifically the European Judicial Board
We should reinforce this institution so that the judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, all the training of judges is essential.
This is something that the Commission cannot do on its own,
but the Commission can stimulate the development of this type of training courses in community law and in the knowledge of the different legal systems.
Then there is a huge difficulty, which is the problem of languages. How can we communicate? Let's say a Spanish judge with a Finnish judge with two different languages.
It is not possible to pretend that judges, besides having to manage their own law, which is already quite complex in itself, are obliged to have knowledge for this type of cases.
What can we do from a practical point of view to facilitate the interpretation and translation task for judges?
What could we do to help them do it?
to present this report, to show any kind of rigor or harshness to the Commission
I think that the work is quite difficult
What I would like to know, taking advantage of the fact that we have here a commissioner who is interested in this issue, what does the commission think can be done to be able to give greater
...a little imprecise, a little voluntarist, and I don't know if from a practical point of view it can have any consequences or if we can get ahead with it.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very happy to be able to conclude the current legislature with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I remember that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we suffered a great maritime accident, the one of the Erika ship near the French coast, which gave a nickname to a first block of legislative proposals intended to cut and avoid accidents.
We thought we had already conjured the danger, but shortly after the coasts of Galicia were ruined with the Chapapote, from another accident even greater than the first, the one of the

Since then, in the Transport Commission we have worked on successive legislative packages, trying to overcome the excessive resistance we find in oil companies, oil companies, classification societies and also in certain member states that rejected our proposals for considering them too demanding.

In these ten years we have approved different directives and regulations, some of which we have had to review again because, due to the cuts caused by the Council, they were not effective in its first edition.

We approved the standards for the introduction of double-hulled vessels, the European Fund for Great Petroleum Catastrophes, and port refuges. Now we review and approve the responsibility of the passengers by sea, the research of the

the community system of monitoring and information on maritime traffic, the control by the state rector of the port and finally the regulation and directive referring to the inspection and recognition of ships organizations.
And all this is good and desirable that it can come into force and be applied by all member states in the shortest possible time.
That's why I feel satisfied.
but the legislature is over, I leave the Parliament and I am sorry for not having achieved that it was established as mandatory the introduction of control systems that exist
are patented to know when and how much fuel and fuel tanks have been illegally poured into the sea by a certain ship.
That is, a kind of black boxes or tachometers that can be inspected by the maritime authorities every time a ship arrives at the port.

I think we owe the marine environment a better care and more severe procedures to cut off so much pollution that we produce and that if we do not do it will affect our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I trust that they will not have to spend another 10 years to control more efficiently the illegal marine waste.
Mr. President, the revision of the Euromiñeta Directive is a matter of great importance that concerns us all, especially the peripheral countries, which feel victims of this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to address the internationalisation of external costs of road transport, imputing three new costs. Atmospheric pollution, acoustic pollution and congestion.

Although the principles that inspire the proposal, who uses and who pollutes pay, are reasonable, it is not, in any way, the solution that is proposed, which will be discriminatory for a sector that has been suffering for months the disastrous effects of the economic crisis.
demonizing the transport of goods by road, or that it was not the objective, has resulted to be the end.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is inopportune and far from achieving the expected objectives of sustainable transport, it would be the death sentence for a large number of small and medium-sized European companies that employ thousands of

in the European Union, who contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that the products reach their final consumer. A consumer who will see how his products are lessened by the application of these rates.
Ladies and gentlemen, we need a sustainable and respectful competitive transport system with the environment, without blocking the road, because it is currently the only way to get everywhere.
Modal change is still a dream, far from being reality.
The European networks, the sea motorways, the cross-border connections are still projects, in some cases, but not reality.
Ladies and gentlemen, when the Titanic of the global economy sinks, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to keep playing, much less for joys.

Thank you, Mr. President. The European Commission, on July 15, 2008, adopted a communication directed to the Council and Parliament recommending the establishment of a strategic association between the European Union and Mexico.
On the other hand, the European Council of Foreign Relations on 13 October recognized Mexico as a strategic partner, waiting for the Parliament's opinion on this matter.
Let us remember that in the seventh meeting of the Mixed Parliamentary Commission of the European Union in Mexico, held at the end of October last year, we said that a
A strategic association between Mexico and the European Union is a necessary impulse to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We will highlight the good moment of relations between both parties and the positive balance of the current global agreement.

We insist on the need for our respective executives to strengthen the collaboration in political, economic and cooperation matters, in the face of the new challenges of all kinds, derived from the financial and economic crisis that our continents are going through.

With the great country that is Mexico, we share values and objectives such as the development of democratic forms of government, the commitment to gender equality, the consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development and the respect for human rights.
We advocate for narrowing cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism and drug trafficking based on shared responsibility principles and strict adherence to international law.
Consequently, we will support the proposal of recommendations on the strategic association European Union of Mexico, which will be submitted to Parliament this morning.
I would like to congratulate all the speakers on the report on microcredits, because they have done a great job.
improved without a doubt the initiative of the Commission.
I understand that the recommendations that are established here will allow us to be the basis for developing a real framework in the European Union for the microcredit sector.
which has been a success in many developing countries, including some European ones, both as an economic activity mechanism and as an instrument to improve social inclusion and employment creation.
but that had not been transferred to the sector or to the community context. And I think it is an opportunity to do so, especially starting from the economic and financial context in which we are.
It is important to reinforce the initiatives that are being carried out here, but we must take more steps.
We must increase the funds available for this microcredit support structure
We must facilitate the availability for people and companies that do not have access to loans. In this sense, I would like to highlight, Madam President, the example of the
the European guarantee for microcredit loans as an instrument that can facilitate this access and that has been included in the report.
And I conclude by saying that this will undoubtedly set the foundations for creating a harmonious framework in the European context that will promote the microcredit sector.

Mr. President, taking advantage of the fact that we are talking about budget, I understand that we must mentalize ourselves so that next year the continuity of the help to coal, indigenous source of essential energy, is negotiated.

And I say this with the due anticipation because, in an unprecedented way, some senior official, confusing public opinion, allowed himself to think in the opposite direction, filtering it to an economic publication.
None of that.
We will have to continue supporting my country's coal after 2012 and I want it to be like that in the session diary.
Please limit yourselves to comply with the current plan and then, from 2012 onwards, with the instrument that we will start negotiating with the sector next year.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, this question, as Mr. Bockland has explained, is very timely, given the diplomatic conference on the Recycling of Bukes Agreement, which will be held in May.
Therefore, I would like to congratulate Mr. Blokland not only for the question but also for the resolution he has prepared.

In the Popular Party we are in favour of the fight against the bad practices and methods that are being used to displace the ships and therefore we support the resolution proposal of Mr. Brockland. But there are some points that concern us

The first is section 3, which he has also mentioned, which says that all the vessels must be considered dangerous waste and, as a consequence, must be in the scope of application of the Basilea Agreement.

We have presented an amendment on this section because there are different interpretations within and outside the European Union and we understand that the Basilea Agreement must be taken into account and not be contradicted by it, but it must be the future international agreement on shipwrecking that defines the details of its application.
The resolution proposal also requires a financing mechanism based on the mandatory contributions of the maritime transport sector.

We seem to be a little hasty to talk about mandatory contributions when we have not yet decided within the OMI what the system that will be adopted for this financing will be. And it seems to me that the European Commission does not have a clear answer to this matter.
Finally, in point 15, the Commission is instructed to clearly establish that the State with jurisdiction over waste is the State responsible.
We believe that it is the Commission's competence to decide this, which must also be decided in an international agreement.

The important thing is to ensure the coherence of the future Convention on the Recycling of Ships and the Convention of Basilea on the Transport Control of Dangerous Waste and its Elimination, and all this taking into account not only the Convention of Basilea but all existing legislation.

Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissaries, colleagues. The first thing I would like to do is congratulate the speaker with whom we have kept a great coincidence in this regard and congratulate us all because in times of economic crisis it is essential to maintain a program like this one with clear positive social effects.

Although we are facing a consultation process from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that in these moments of economic uncertainty, from Brussels and Strasbourg, we are not exclusively concerned

We are not only concerned about a recovery of the financial system, but we are fully aware that social policies, especially those that support those who need it most, the poorest of the European Union, have to grow.

This food distribution programme must continue to be considered part of the Common Agricultural Policy. Here we agree with the Commission. In addition to the fact that European agriculture has a marked social character, because it is an instrument that works, because now it is needed more than ever and because it must continue to work.

From the Socialist Group, as well as the speaker, we are against this program being co-financed between the European Union and the Member States, as this would mean a discrimination between States according to their wealth, which could be the case that the program cannot be put into practice in the most needed countries.

It is not understood that now, when more is needed, the Commission wants to save money on the most social facet of the PAC, especially considering that every year there are budget surpluses in the agricultural budget.
Community-based financing is essential for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries and above all the most in need.
43 million potential beneficiaries of this program demand a greater effort and in no case should budgetary expenses be saved.
Austerity, yes, but not with the poorest.
And it is precisely to guarantee that it reaches the citizen of all member states that the program must cover the entire route of distributed food.

Therefore, from the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, we have presented an amendment so that all the expenses derived from distribution, including transport, storage, and administration, are subjugated with community funds.
We also agree with the speaker that food must be preferably community and quality.
is the coherent position with the one maintained by this Parliament in other similar programs that we recently discussed in this Chamber, such as the fruit distribution plan in schools.
That's all, thank you very much.
We hope that the Commission takes into account the position of this Parliament when it votes and above all that the plan is put in motion in the European Union as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile regions on our planet.

The consequences of an exploitation without restrictions of its natural resources would be catastrophic not only for the immediate environment and for the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The de-frozen of large areas has put these risks to the present, so it is necessary a new regulation of global reach to protect the Arctic, similar to the one that already exists for Antarctica, even taking into account the differences that have already been highlighted in the debate.

It is necessary an international treaty between all the parties involved, including the European Union, to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable nature of human activities of all kinds and regulate multilaterally the navigation of the new maritime routes that are made accessible.
The Council of the Arctic, during its several years of existence, has been a model of cooperation to manage common problems.

In these moments of difficulty and uncertainty, we must raise to higher levels that spirit and that harmony to prevent the states of the area or other international actors from setting themselves in geostrategic fountains, forgetting what the common objective must be, the preservation of a great shared patrimony.
Mr. President, unlike the two speakers who just preceded me, I agree with most of the speakers.
This is a good directive, an excellent directive, aimed at protecting the interpreters.
When it is said that we must look for a more intelligent model of doing business, in reality what is being said is to end intellectual property.
because you can only do business if there is a right established
We already have a national right

achieved in the field of the legal affairs commission thanks to the work of the speaker Mr. Crowley and the different speakers in the shadows such as Mrs. McGill and Mr. Tubón.
I think it is a magnificent directive, a directive that will enhance the creation of intellectual property.
and also in that directive are included some recommendations regarding the continuation of the work.
I believe that the approval by this Chamber of this report and I hope that the Council aligns the lines of the Council of the Commission and the Parliament serves to the next legislature

The Commission should follow this path, make proposals to the Parliament and move forward in the field of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a great institution based on a common culture.

Yes, Mr. President, the information you give me is correct, but the impression that we, the European Parliamentarians, and in short, the European citizens, have is that we have a very dangerous lagoon in the community law.
At this moment, as the fiscal demands in each of the member states are being reinforced, mobility is almost impossible.
And when we ask the Commission, the reason for the pragmatic approach is that the Commission never finds support in the Council.

We are in a vicious circle, due to which the Commission is referring us to the Council and the Council is referring us to the Commission. However, the reality is that the citizens who live in this Europe that we want to build do not have the possibility of living in different countries or establishing relations as a consequence of the heavy fiscal burden that fiscal harmonization can be.
Can the council do something to get us out of this vicious circle?
Madam President, I am pleased that Mr. Tajani has come, because he has the advantage of being a European Parliamentarian.
And as a European Parliamentarian, I know that the frustration that we have as European Parliamentarians with respect to the application of the Community Law has been experienced.

Now, in the Parliament we tend to get involved with the Commission. I think we are asking the Commission for an impossible mission, because all the community law and all the application of community law is based on indirect application.

The Commission has only a few officials in the headquarters, where some complaints come in and some possibilities of action. But at this moment, the tendency is to limit the budgetary faculties, so the Commission will not have the possibility to do so.
All the application of the Community Law is based on the actions of the national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, national officials.
And here in this aspect I do not think we can demand too much from the Commission.
What we have to do is help the Commission. And I think that in Ms. Frassoni's report there are some points that can be useful to get this application.
I mean those related to the correlation of directives, the collaboration of the national parliaments and the performance of the national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, in a mission led by my colleague, my colleague from the group here, Marian, I had the opportunity to visit
and to be present in this court and to be aware of the immense work that this court was doing not only for Sierra Leone but for all humanity.
The Sierra Leona Special Court, as has been said here, has certainly set a precedent.

A precedent because, as the resolution indicates, it is the first international court funded by voluntary contributions. It is the first court to be created in the country where the alleged crimes took place. And it is also the first court, as has already been pointed out, in which an ex-first minister has been judged.

For all this, not only because it is a precedent, but because it is a reference for other courts that have been created at their disposal, such as Rwanda, Old Yugoslavia, Cambodia or Lebanon, we consider it essential that this resolution be approved, in which we have been working together with the court for several months.
Two years ago we approved a resolution to support its financing. Two years ago the court was going through a difficult period in which it was left without
and did not have enough support. We must thank the European Commission for its financial support for this court.

Now, we ask for two things. First, that the condemned people fulfill their sentences. The functioning of the Tribunal that ends next year is not at stake, but the legacy that this Tribunal will leave us. And secondly, obviously, all of this has to be accompanied by a greater financing.
In short, the Special Court of Sierra Leone is an example and a reference for all of us and all the courts that have judged war crimes.

It is an example and a reference and it is a lesson that the second poorest country on this planet is giving us. In which, when entering the court, we saw a slogan written that was, without justice there is no peace.
And that is precisely why we have the moral obligation, not only as Europeans but as human beings, that the legacy of this Tribunal remains permanent in history.
Yes, thank you Mr. President. I would like to thank you for your kind words. Mr. Vice President of the Commission, thank you very much once again for demonstrating, as you did in the third package

that its political category has been able to promote an agreement close to the Council and make it possible for Parliament, Council and Commission to agree on this matter and in these days where the Legislature ends.
I think we have to congratulate ourselves
I thank the close collaboration of the speakers, both in the Jury Committee and in the Environment Committee.

I thank you and I reiterate the work and collaboration of the speakers in the shadow. And, in short, I believe that the one who tomorrow we adopt a first reading agreement on such an important norm, which undoubtedly comes to complete the work of the

The third maritime package is a success for this Parliament and for the European Union in all its institutions and justifies once again the co-decision process, which is useful and allows constructive dialogue in favour of all the citizens of the European Union.
I want to answer the question of the Commissioner who knows about my friendship and affection for her and, indeed, my friendship and affection for Mr. Orbán.
But the commissioner has not said a single word about the recommendation of the defender of the people.
The people's representative, who knows all the arguments that the commissioner has given us, has made a precise recommendation that the commission seems to ignore in all its extremes.

I don't even want Mrs. Cuneva to answer me because, evidently, she is not the one who has the data. But all the data she has given me are in line with what we knew and with what the defender of the people also knows. And she doesn't tell us if, effectively,

Despite all that, and as the defender of the people who knows that recommends that the norm be changed, he does not tell us if the Commission will assume what the defender of the people asks and what the Parliament recommends according to what the defender of the people has asked.

Thank you Mr. President. I believe that the proposals of regulation that the Commission has submitted are important and necessary. And on the other hand, it was also important and necessary that from the
we insist on the principles that the two speakers of the European Parliament have insisted on, Mr. Zivieska and Mr. Depré. And it is the principle of community competence.

It is a matter of community competence, in which for practical reasons it is convenient to maintain certain competences of the states, but as Mr. Barró has said, limited in terms of their scope and in terms of time.
Community competence is unavailable and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor the Parliament have the capacity to renounce that community competence.

This is an exceptional procedure. I think that the amendments that we have discussed and that we present and that I think will be approved by the Parliament tomorrow will allow the approval of this package of measures in first reading.

But I also hope that the Commission, in the future, and starting from this, we can make progress in the elaboration of a true European private law, which is increasingly necessary, as Mr. Sogor has highlighted in his last speech.
We are talking about the problems that directly affect people and as long as we are able to solve these problems, people will realize that the European Union has a function.

In conclusion, Mr. President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Mr. De Brey and Mr. Zvieska, and I would like to thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to collaborate with us on this issue.

Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, I have signed this resolution and I have asked to intervene in this plan because I witnessed the so-called expulsion, but which was in the end a kidnapping of our colleague Luis Herrero.

I also found that it is a common norm in Venezuela to persecute politicians, to abuse power by the Chavist regime, to intimidate the adversary, to threaten, to despise the dignity of people and the tortuous use of justice, among other things.

Manuel Chávez's case is the drop that has eaten the glass and has given rise to this resolution. But there are thousands of cases as bloody as his that are cited in the resolution and others that are not cited
as is the case of Elige Ocedeño, who was born in the humble Caracas neighborhood of Petare, well known for its danger and also because a mayor who was not of the Chavista regime voted.
Eligio studied thanks to the help of others and specifically Citibank, he managed to found his own business, the Caracas Bank, and also then lived normally helping the most needy.
Today, however, he is sentenced to prison in Caracas and, after two years of being detained without any legal imputation,
It is their only crime to be part of the economic hierarchy.
Another case is Nisson Moreno, student leader of the University of the Andes, several times elected for the university council and president of the Federation of Universal Centres.
In 2003, he won the elections to the current Minister of the Interior and Justice, and this is his crime.
Today he is accused of murder, in the state of frustration, of violent, harmful acts, and all this despite having been exonerated from such accusations.

Situations like yours are the daily life in this country where the persecution of the adversary, with the spirit of excluding him from political life and discouraging dissidence, has become the facts of everyday life.

However, from here it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy despite the difficulties. I am sure that democracy will be imposed and that President Chávez will be deposed in the polls.

Thank you, Mrs. President. Mr. Commissioner, indeed, it is undeniable that the situation has advanced in recent times. But despite all the progress, the south of the Union is burning and burning more and more.
That is why the resolution that this Parliament is going to make cannot be a resolution that would be used to highlight the great concern that other people's grievances cause us.
Forest fires are caused by some or other causes, but no one can deny that they are fed on climate change.

and regardless of the responsibilities that may exist in some States or in some autonomous communities, the truth is that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act with speed and to put all resources it has, which are not few, at its disposal.
Neither the victims, nor the suffered damages, nor the needs for reforestation understand of bureaucracy, nor can they understand of budgetary deficiencies.
We must prioritise and act. In this case, we must act by modifying strategies, mobilising resources, increasing them and optimally coordinating preventive policies, demanding that the

In this case, it is the responsibility of the states that will lack them. But assuming that this is not a problem of a southern European state and that climate change does not affect only a few states, it affects everyone and it is a common cause.
That is why one of the main tasks of this Parliament is to achieve that the European Union achieves clear and effective commitments to the next summit of Copenhagen.
to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions to the maximum. Because they are evidently at the base of the fires and their causes, and these, in turn, are the causes of more climate change.
Therefore, to approve this resolution is now the challenge of this Parliament, with all certainty.
But that this commission's challenge is fulfilled, if you really want to prevent the south of the union, which does exist, from burning.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Thank you very much for giving me the floor. I turn to Mr. Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I follow you with great interest and with great respect since a long time ago, since you were governor in a country that is very close to us and very dear to us, which is Portugal.

First of all, I would like to congratulate Mrs. McGuinness for this initiative in which the important role that the PAC plays in dealing with the needs of food supply on an international scale is shown.

Now that the European Commission seems to want to reduce the weight of the PAC within the community budget, it must be said very clearly that the PAC is no longer a priority, but food supply should be. And in recent decades it has been seen that without the PAC, food supply is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Agriculture cannot be compared to other sectors of the economy capable of prospering in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union to be able to move forward his business and the Union needs the farmer to maintain a agricultural model capable of providing enough and quality food to a more and more demanding citizen.
I think, therefore, that a change in the direction of the PAC should take place, but not disappear.

For this, it would be necessary to guarantee direct aid to farmers, as well as to restore a policy of management of agricultural markets that provides greater stability in prices, which would benefit not only farmers, but also consumers and third-party countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practices to promote a balance of relations between the different agents of the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a fairer distribution of commercial margins.
In addition, a policy of information to the European consumer is needed, which emphasizes the efforts made by community producers to comply with the EU regulations on the environment.
food security and animal welfare, because community producers have to compete with the productions of third countries where very low standards are applied for importation.

Mr. President, Madam Secretary, we are in a key moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, after the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, focuses not only on economic and social aspects but also on the territorial one.
territorial cohesion pursues a harmonious development between territories to ensure that its citizens can maximize their territorial singularities.
But to achieve this objective, it is also necessary to advance in the field of cooperation between the regions of the Union that face the same challenges and the same problems.

This is the objective pursued by the European Union's strategy for the Atlantic region. A common perspective to address the common challenges faced by the states of the region, among others, marine research, maritime surveillance and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is in tune with the 2020 strategy and the policies of the European Union for the period after 2013, especially with regional policy and maritime policy.
But, ladies and gentlemen, first and foremost, it is necessary that this strategy be based on a renewed multi-level governance, based on a closer participation of public authorities
regional and local, member states, the European Union and the interested parties of the private sector and civil society organizations, including organizations and interregional networks.

a disease against which we fought through the activated vaccine, whose use involves the creation of restricted areas for the circulation of animals, because the use of these vaccines can cause unwanted virus circulation in non-infected animals.

What the economy and European companies need is trust.
Account audits are now burdened by the lack of concentration and independence of the auditors and do not contribute to generate that desired confidence that relaunch our economy.
it would not be wrong to consider eliminating the legal obligation of the account audits.
Why not?
If we want to regain the confidence of the markets and in the markets, we must carry out a profound audit reform so that they are of real added value and not a mere legal burden.
The big auditors use the audit services as a presentation card for their future clients.
Once familiarized with the company, they offer more expensive complementary services with which to compensate the low prices of the strict audit.
We have a problem of price distortion in the sector.

Thank you, Mrs. President. From the European Parliament, I want to pay tribute to all women. Despite the fact that we have made a lot of progress since March 1911, when women went out to the streets to ask for votes and better working conditions, I think that the equality of women is still very far away.
Today women can work without having to ask for permission from anyone, but in many cases they still charge less than men for a similar job, which is unacceptable.
There is also the need to remind women in the rural world that their work is ignored.
I think that another uncomfortable reality, but that we must continue to denounce, is the violence against women.

Only this year there has been an excessive number of women murdered, not to mention the serious threats of those who believe they have the right to exercise physical or psychological violence against them.
It's time to say enough and say it loud and clear.

From this Parliament I reiterate my commitment to the European Order for Victim Protection and to the Directive of Victims that was presented by the Commission and that will be voted on, God willing, next month of June.
We also have to say, and I would like to remind you, that maternity is still an obstacle for women's progression and I think it is a trend that should be changed.
I want to send a message of hope and with the help of many women and more and more men we have to advance on the path of equality, opportunities, rights and also duties.
We have traveled a lot, but there is still a lot to do.
I have to admit that I don't believe in the quotas in a profound way, but I have to tell you that there is something we have to do.

I would like to thank my colleagues and of course Mrs. Reding for opening this debate and for advancing on this path so that women can recover the place they deserve and with them you can count on my help.

Thank you, Mr. President. We need a common European strategy against diabetes and we need a recommendation from the Council that tells the States that they have to increase research, even with stem cells, that they have to coordinate their results to optimize them, that they have to establish programs of healthy food and life habits

But I am sure that those who have problems now will have more quality of life and we will be as states, as council and as commission, fulfilling one of the obligations that we have, which is to protect the health of our citizens.
Mr. President, of the many issues that this debate raises, I would like to highlight the issue of the market of emissions rights. A market that was born with defects, certainly,
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have meant a drastic reduction in the price of carbon. That is, it is so low that it is cheap to contaminate.
It is therefore urgent to reform the design of a policy on that market because its deterioration threatens all the green efforts, all the green policy of the European Union.
If the emission rights are not valued, the increase in emissions is being encouraged. The polluting industries will not invest in new techniques. And what is worse,
The financing of important projects will be in danger, such as projects related to energy efficiency or carbon storage plants.
This is the risk.
It is up to us, the Commission and the Parliament, to judge it.

The European social model that we so much presume does not only lie in our pension systems, education or health, but also in a way of understanding the balance between the employer and the worker within the companies.

The labour reform that the Spanish government has approved, without dialogue and without consensus, breaks with that social model and takes us away from the objectives of the 2020 strategy, both in terms of creating employment and in terms of its quality.
A labor reform alone does not create employment, it is done by economic growth.
What a labor law does is define in what conditions workers enter companies, in what conditions they remain in them and in what conditions they leave them.
and with this reform where 80% of workers will be unprotected because they will not be subject to collective agreements, where they will be fired for a drop in the income of companies

that could change their schedules unilaterally. What is clear is that workers will enter with greater precariousness, will remain in the labour market with more fear and will leave it with less compensation.

Therefore, this reform that is against the European social model and that is committed to the competitiveness of the Spanish economy only in relation to the conditions of the workers deserves a general strike, as the one that is to be convened tomorrow in Spain in defence of this social model.

This forces us to deal with the vulnerability problem from a transversal point of view, taking into account the different needs, capacities and circumstances of consumers.

or the available options or their ignorance of the existing claims and compensation systems, especially in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

To solve deficiencies, that is, problems, it is necessary to adopt a strategy to reinforce vulnerable consumers and that both the Commission and the Member States introduce specific measures in their legislation to guarantee adequate protection

that goes beyond mere information, especially in those matters where the level has been shown to be higher and where the largest number of complaints from consumers is recorded. The financial sector, whose complexity implies that, in power, any consumer can become vulnerable.

high-containing food in fats, salts and sugars, and children and young people, who are the most sensitive to the advertising of these foods. The transport sector, which continues to have difficulties when the vulnerable travel. The energy and telecommunications sector,

where the lack of transparency causes, in some cases, additional difficulty for consumers. For example, in the energy sector, when determining the rate that best fits their needs. In access to justice, where consumers can find difficulties in accessing the necessary mechanisms.

Thank you, Mrs. President. Since I entered this Parliament, I have not stopped denouncing female genital mutilation.
that silent and accepted crime that millions of women and girls in the world suffer. 70 million, I repeat, 70 million.

...an unbearable figure for those who stop studying the terrible consequences of these practices......that are hidden under the disguise of psychological, health, religious reasons, all of them false...

The truth is that the ablation practiced, preferably in girls of 14 and even of 1 year, can lead to death due to hemorrhagic collapse and, in the best case, cause and bring strong psychological consequences due to trauma.
From Europe we must fight with all our strength to eradicate this violation of human rights, which violates the right to equal opportunities, puts health at risk,
It is about mistreatment, cruelty, torture against girls. And this denigrant treatment also exists in Europe.
For this, we must activate all the prevention mechanisms that our legal system has and I encourage our judges to act to avoid the genital mutilation
of girls in Europe, punishing those who commit it. May the law in Europe speak with one voice when it comes to fighting mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I ask civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns
We still have a long way to go, but we are many who will not stop because we owe it to 70 million mutilated women.

not because it was bad legislation, the legislation was very good, but as has been said, it happened the recent events of all known and they showed that there was a certain

The work of the speaker, Mr. President, is very good, but I want to take this opportunity to say here, in this framework, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can warn.
We forget what Pufendorf taught us, that the general laws must be few and their meaning must be understood correctly.
Therefore, those who promote it must use all the clarity that is possible.
and Montesquieu always insisted that the legal language must be precise and concise.
In other words, we must avoid esoteric talk, full of neologisms and unjustified linguistic loans, because it generates an evil network where traps are tied and arbitrariness is settled.

It is frequent that even law professionals, judges and lawyers despair before our texts.
The good prose, dear colleagues, is the courtesy of the legislator and a way to show his respect to the citizen.

among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of responsibility to protect or the concept of human security.

is cybersecurity and cybersecurity. Reports that we also discussed today and whose suggestions we hope to be included in the new European cybersecurity strategy.

Ladies and gentlemen, it is no longer time to discuss a supposed dichotomy between austerity and growth.
Some of us are making efforts and sacrifices to correct the deficit.
But Spain, like so many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity and create employment.
And with this budget, we can't get anywhere. First of all, it constitutes a missile the line of flotation.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with many fewer resources, and above all if what is there is distributed unfairly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that will subtly and subtly mean the disappearance of the possibilities of growth and above all any vestige of solidarity. And this is precisely the direction that the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path that the Commission points to, to whom we must thank for its commitment to point out a different route.

At this point, in the need for union, in the need for shared efforts, I want to thank Mr. Barroso for making a strong statement of interpretation of the treaties for a supposed secessionist in the heart of the union.

He made it clear, as guardian of the treaties, that if a part of a member state separates as an independent state, it becomes considered a third country and therefore the declarations and the effects of the treaty will not affect it in any way.

I hope, Mr. Vice-President, in the absence of the President, that this can be collected and that this safe and constant doctrine of the Commission can continue to remain alive for the guarantee of all.
